newsitem.title: USA: Clinton aide urges N. Irish loyalists to stay calm.
newsitem.headline: Clinton aide urges N. Irish loyalists to stay calm.

text.p: President Bill Clinton's national security adviser urged British loyalists in Northern Ireland on Tuesday not to be provoked to violence by a bomb attack on British Army headquarters there.

"We join all who care about Northern Ireland's future in calling on the loyalists not to be provoked into a futile and deadly spiral of violence by yesterday's attack," said White House adviser Anthony Lake, who has been central to Clinton's efforts to further peace in the province. "It could destroy the future of Northern Ireland," Lake said.

In a speech at Georgetown University, Lake said the double car bomb attack at British Army barracks in Lisburn near Belfast, in which 20 soldiers and 11 civilians were hurt, was "despicable" and "an outrageous act of terrorism".

The attack has been claimed by a shadowy Irish republican group, the Continuity Army Council, although some British officials believe the Irish Republican Army, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland, was responsible.
Lake said the attack "deserves the strongest possible condemnation by civiized men and women everywhere." He added: "Those responsible must be brought to justice and as soon as possible."

Lake said it would be a tragedy if the loyalists, who want to retain British rule, abandoned their own ceasefire. He said the Clinton administration, which has made settling the Northern Ireland conflict a top priority and is helping mediate peace talks, would do all it could to keep the peace process on track.
